isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CATERPILLAR 3406B -1991 - SYSTEM COMPONENTS AND OPERATION - Kysor Shutdown System

svcproc.title: Kysor Shutdown System
svcproc.para: The three primary components of the Kysor system are:

Kysor Control Module - The Kysor control module is a time delay switch that remains closed for approximately 30 seconds after the engine is started and the start switch is released. When the engine starter is engaged, power from circuit 19B activates the 30-second delay, closing the switch between contacts 1 and 3. Ignition current from F3 (20 AMP) fuse, to J1 ignition connector, then circuit 19A goes through the control module contacts (1 to 3) and on circuit 19M/97A to activate the Run Relay. Normally after 30 seconds of engine operation, the oil pressurestat NO (normally open) contacts have closed and control of the Run Relay is through the pressurestat and the alarmstat; then power on circuits 19M/97A to the Run Relay keeps it activated.

After 30 seconds the Control Module switch will open. If the pressurestat NO switch (closed with 5 psi oil pressure) or the NC (normally closed) switch of the alarmstat is not closed, the Run Relay will be deactivated, shutting down the engine.

Pressurestat - The pressurestat is in the circuit to monitor engine oil pressure. It consists of two sets of contacts which are sensitive to engine oil pressure. One set of contacts (normally open) controls the voltage to the Run Relay control circuit through the C (common) terminal on the alarmstat. The other set of contacts (normally closed) controls the ignition voltage to the alarm and engine shutdown light.

The NC contacts of the pressurestat control the alarm system. When the vehicle is started, the normally closed pressurestat contacts stay closed until the oil pressure exceeds approximately 9 psi, then they open and the alarm is turned off. If the oil pressure drops below approximately 9 psi, the NC (normally closed) contacts will close, sounding the alarm and illuminating the warning light. The alarm will continue to sound until the key switch is turned off.

The NO (normally open) contacts of the pressurestat control the ignition voltage needed to keep the Run Relay activated. With the ignition switch in the ON position, the normally open contacts will close when the engine oil pressure exceeds approximately 5 psi. Ignition voltage will then pass through the pressurestat to the alarmstat to keep the Run Relay activated. If the engine oil pressure drops below 5 psi, the NO (normally open) contacts will open and deactivate the Run Relay, shutting down the engine.

Alarmstat -The alarmstat also has two sets of contacts. These contacts are sensitive to engine coolant temperature. The NC (normally closed) contacts provide an ignition voltage path from the pressurestat to keep the Run Relay activated. The NO (normally open) contacts control the alarm system in the event operating temperatures are exceeded.

The NC (normally closed) alarmstat contacts that control the Run Relay will remain closed unless the engine coolant temperature exceeds 225 degrees F. If the NC (normally closed) contacts open, the Run Relay will be deactivated, shutting down the engine.

The NO (normally open) alarmstat contacts that control the alarm system will close, sounding the alarm, if engine coolant temperatures exceed 219 degrees F (six degrees before engine shutdown will occur). If the NO (normally open) contacts close, voltage is applied to the alarm and to the engine shutdown light.

In summary, the pressurestat NC (normally closed) contacts will close if oil pressure drops to approximately 9 psi and activate the alarm system. If oil pressure drops to 5 psi, the NO (normally open) contacts will open and deactivate the Run Relay, shutting down the engine. The alarmstat NO (normally open) contacts will close at 219 degrees F and activate the alarm system. At 225 degrees, the NC (normally closed) contacts will open and deactivate the Run Relay, shutting down the engine.
